verses.text: Manasseh was twelve years old when he became king, and he reigned in Jerusalem fifty-five years. His mother’s name was Hephzibah.
verses.comment: Opening statement about Manasseh; consistent with the original wording.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the eyes of the LORD, following the detestable practices of the nations the LORD had driven out before the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Stresses Manasseh’s evil deeds according to the Lord.

verses.text: He rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed, and he set up altars for Baal, made an Asherah pole, as Ahab king of Israel had done, and worshiped all the host of heaven and served them.
verses.comment: Hezekiah’s reforms are undone; reference to practices like those of Ahab.

verses.text: He built altars in the house of the LORD, about which the LORD had said, 'In Jerusalem I will put My name.'
verses.comment: Describes idolatry inside the temple, which was forbidden.

verses.text: He built altars for all the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the LORD.
verses.comment: Host of heaven: refers to worshiping stars, sun, and moon.

verses.text: He made his son pass through the fire, practiced divination and sought omens, and dealt with mediums and spiritists. He did much evil in the eyes of the LORD, arousing His anger.
verses.comment: "Pass through the fire" refers to child sacrifice to pagan gods.

verses.text: He set up the carved image of Asherah that he had made in the house of which the LORD had said to David and to Solomon his son, 'In this house and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel, I will put My name forever.'
verses.comment: Direct reference to God choosing the temple in Jerusalem.

verses.text: 'And I will not again cause the feet of Israel to wander out of the land that I gave to their fathers, if only they will be careful to do all that I have commanded them, and all the law that My servant Moses commanded them.'
verses.comment: Repeats God’s promise and the condition of obedience.

verses.text: But they did not listen, and Manasseh led them astray, to do more evil than the nations whom the LORD destroyed before the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Judah’s sins worse than those of earlier nations.

verses.text: And the LORD spoke by His servants the prophets, saying,
verses.comment: Prophetic warning is standard in this section.

verses.text: 'Because Manasseh king of Judah has done these detestable things, acting more wickedly than all the Amorites who were before him, and has also made Judah to sin with his idols,
verses.comment: Reference to Amorites as a symbol of extreme wickedness.

verses.text: therefore thus says the LORD, the God of Israel: Look, I am bringing upon Jerusalem and Judah such disaster that the ears of everyone who hears of it will tingle.
verses.comment: "Ears...will tingle" is a Hebrew idiom for shocking news.

verses.text: And I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line of Samaria and the plumb line of the house of Ahab, and I will wipe Jerusalem as one wipes a dish, wiping it and turning it upside down.
verses.comment: "Measuring line" and "plumb line" symbolize judgment. The dish image is literal from the Hebrew.

verses.text: And I will forsake the remnant of My inheritance and give them into the hand of their enemies, and they shall become a prey and a spoil to all their enemies,
verses.comment: God's abandonment because of unrelenting sin.

verses.text: because they have done what is evil in My eyes and have provoked Me to anger since the day their fathers came out of Egypt, even to this day.'
verses.comment: Sin has been continual since Egypt.

verses.text: Moreover, Manasseh shed very much innocent blood, until he had filled Jerusalem from one end to another, besides his sin by which he made Judah to sin, by doing what was evil in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: "Innocent blood" refers to murder of the innocent, possibly prophets.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Manasseh, all that he did, and the sin he committed, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Reference to other historical sources; typical in Kings.

verses.text: And Manasseh slept with his fathers and was buried in the garden of his own house, in the garden of Uzza, and his son Amon became king in his place.
verses.comment: Burial in the garden of Uzza; unique burial location.

verses.text: Amon was twenty-two years old when he became king, and he reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Meshullemeth, the daughter of Haruz of Jotbah.
verses.comment: Standard introduction for Amon’s reign; preserves original wording.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD, as Manasseh his father had done.
verses.comment: Amon follows in Manasseh’s sinful steps.

verses.text: He walked in all the ways that his father walked, and served the idols that his father had served, and worshiped them.
verses.comment: Emphasizes continuity of idolatry.

verses.text: He abandoned the LORD, the God of his fathers, and did not walk in the way of the LORD.
verses.comment: Amon’s apostasy is explicit.

verses.text: And the servants of Amon conspired against him and killed the king in his own house.
verses.comment: Assassination of Amon; matches Hebrew structure.

verses.text: But the people of the land killed all those who conspired against King Amon, and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his place.
verses.comment: People’s reaction restores the Davidic line.

verses.text: Now the rest of the acts of Amon that he did, are they not written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah?
verses.comment: Typical closing reference in Kings.

verses.text: He was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza, and Josiah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Final note on Amon’s burial and Josiah’s succession.
